 11: # "ctypedef" assigns a corresponding compile-time type to DTYPE_t. For
 12: # every type in the numpy module there's a corresponding compile-time
 13: # type with a _t-suffix.
 14: ctypedef np.int_t DTYPE_t
 15: # The builtin min and max functions works with Python objects, and are
 16: # so very slow. So we create our own.
 17: #  - "cdef" declares a function which has much less overhead than a normal
 18: #    def function (but it is not Python-callable)
 19: #  - "inline" is passed on to the C compiler which may inline the functions
 20: #  - The C type "int" is chosen as return type and argument types
 21: #  - Cython allows some newer Python constructs like "a if x else b", but
 22: #    the resulting C file compiles with Python 2.3 through to Python 3.0 beta.
+23: cdef inline int int_max(int a, int b): return a if a >= b else b

 25: # "def" can type its arguments but not have a return type. The type of the
 26: # arguments for a "def" function is checked at run-time when entering the
 27: # function.
 28: #
 29: # The arrays f, g and h is typed as "np.ndarray" instances. The only effect
 30: # this has is to a) insert checks that the function arguments really are
 31: # NumPy arrays, and b) make some attribute access like f.shape[0] much
 32: # more efficient. (In this example this doesn't matter though.)
 33: cimport cython

 39:     # The "cdef" keyword is also used within functions to type variables. It
 40:     # can only be used at the top indendation level (there are non-trivial
 41:     # problems with allowing them in other places, though we'd love to see
 42:     # good and thought out proposals for it).
 43:     #
 44:     # For the indices, the "int" type is used. This corresponds to a C int,
 45:     # other C types (like "unsigned int") could have been used instead.
 46:     # Purists could use "Py_ssize_t" which is the proper Python type for
 47:     # array indices.
+48:     cdef int vmax = f.shape[0]
  __pyx_v_vmax = (__pyx_v_f->dimensions[0]);

+49:     cdef int wmax = f.shape[1]
